Production of “green hydrogen” through water electrolysis is attracting considerable attention in recent years, due to the high demand for green energy technologies. The efficiency of water electrolysis depends on the electrocatalytic activity of anodic and cathodic electrocatalysts. Currently, utilizing Pt and RuO2-based electrocatalysts is expensive in terms of commercial aspects. Therefore, growing research for inventing efficient and cheap electrocatalysts is undergoing rigorously. In this work, we have synthesized, biomass-derived electrocatalysts with intrinsically implanted heteroatoms as hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions in alkaline electrolytes. The biomass carbon catalyst is derived from the carbonation of the Acorus Calamus plant “root”. The derived carbon is activated by KOH treatment (C-750). The resultant carbon powder is characterized by various physiochemical and electrochemical characterization techniques. The C-750 catalyst is found to have excellent morphology, surface area (3488 m²/g), pore size (4.08 nm), pore volume (1.10 cc/g), and intrinsically doped N. The HRTEM analysis of C-750 reveals well-distributed microporous and graphitic surfaces. When used as an electrocatalyst for HER and OER analysis, the C-750 exhibited appreciable electrocatalytic activity with an overpotential of -0.330 V and 0.563 V vs. RHE, respectively at the current density of -10.0 mA/cm2. In addition, the C-750 catalyst also showed excellent stability with almost zero degradation in a chronoamperometric measurement carried out for 10 hrs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acorus Calamus Carbonization Nanosheets Mesoporous Bifunctional electrocatalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Recently, the energy crisis has arisen around the globe because the global population is increasing together with rapid industrialization for the advancement of society. Currently utilized fossil fuel-based energy sources are known to negatively affect the environment by increasing CO2 emissions thus rapidly increasing the global earth's temperatures. Therefore, a lot of attention has been paid to replacing fossil fuel-based energy with renewable/green energy sources. Among several alternative options, H2-based energy sources are attracting considerable interest, especially the production of green H2 through the electrolysis of water. The efficiency of the water electrolysis system depends on the potential of electrocatalysts used for the oxidation of H2O. Typically, H2O undergoes oxidation at the anode with the evolution of oxygen (oxygen evolution reaction, OER) and reduction of H + ions to H2 gas at the cathode (hydrogen evolution reaction, HER). Overall, the electrolysis of H2O plays a paramount role in several energy-efficient devices such as metal-air batteries, fuel cells, rechargeable batteries, etc. [1]. To date, most conventional, efficient electrocatalysts in use are made up of noble metals such as Pt for HER, Ir/IrO2, and Ru/RuO2 for OER reactions [2–5]. However, the commercialization of these energy conversion devices is largely hindered due to the use of expensive noble metal-based catalysts. Further, the low metal reserves on the earth's crust increase the catalyst's production cost. In addition, these noble metal catalysts are prone to degradation under acidic and alkaline conditions, therefore, offering poor durability over long time operational conditions. Furthermore, these precious metal catalysts also have their preferential pH at which they work, further limiting their applications in a wide range of pH-independent devices. Therefore, it is paramount to discover bifunctional electrocatalysts which are efficient and at the same time cost-effective along with greater stability than the noble metal-based catalysts, which not only reduce the cost of hydrogen/oxygen production, and also simplify the equipment cost thereby increasing the feasibility of practical implications [6–9]. Hence, the development of non-noble metal/metal-free based electrocatalysts at the same time earth-abundant, inexpensive nontoxic/environmentally friendly features, is gaining attractive research for energy conversion, energy storage and environmental applications [10–13]. Therefore, the synthesis of efficient electrocatalysts with favourable onset potential, acceptable overpotential, and superior stability for both HER and OER, are highly desired for practical applications. In recent years, several researchers proposed alternative electrocatalysts to precious metal catalysts made up of transition metals such as Fe, Co, Mo, W, and Ni in their form of oxides/ hydroxides/sulfides/nitrides/phosphides towards both HER/OER activities [14–17]. Regulating the morphology of the catalysts in the form of, nanowires, nanosheets, and hierarchical structures for the electrolyte penetration and gaseous evolution, enhancing electrical conductivities helps in faster electrode kinetics, enhancing the catalyst architectures offers, structural stability to the catalyst [18,19]. In recent times, carbon and carbon-based nanocomposites have been paid greater attention due to their superb electronic conductivity, excellent stability, large specific surface area, and adequate porosity. In this context, carbon and its composites have been utilized for OER and HER applications [20–22]. Further, it is well established that doping of carbon materials with hetero atoms such as N, S, P, and B further enhances the electrocatalytic properties of un-doped carbons by enhancing charge density/spin density around the doped carbons which induces special properties, increases the electronic conductus, modifies the electronic band structures, changes the morphology of the carbon materials. The nitrogen shows high electron affinity than that of carbon and the carbon atoms adjacent to nitrogen dopants counterbalance this electron affinity by creating a net positive charge density and it is favorable for electrocatalytic reactions, including OER and HER reactions [23–26]. In this context, a large range of doped-carbon-based materials has been used such as graphene, graphene oxide, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers and fullerenes are effectively used for energy and environmental remediation [18,27–30]. These materials possess fantastic properties such as high surface area, outstanding electronic, thermal, and mechanical properties, porosity, pore volume, etc. However, the synthesis of such materials is not cost-effective because their starting materials are expensive, require special equipment and reaction conditions, and most importantly, they are not sustainable. In the search for a cheap, sustainable source of carbons, recently, the activated carbons derived from biomass and plant waste is receiving great attention because of their nontoxicity, abundant sources with a high surface area desirable porosity, and excellent stability [31–33]. In this perspective, the synthesis of carbon nanomaterials from abundant natural plants and biomass has been utilized such as, rice husks [34], coir pith [35], corncobs [36], peanut root nodules [37], coffee waste [38], Indian Ooty Varkey [39], etc. have been used as a source materials to synthesize the carbon particles. Subsequently, the obtained carbon particles were activated with various chemical activating agents such as KOH, H3PO4, and ZnCl2 to enhance the surface area and porosity of the carbons [40–43]. Despite this, the electrocatalytic activity of the biomass-derived catalysts is still inferior to state-of-the-art Pt/Ir/RuO2-based catalysts. The electrocatalytic activity can be further increased either by enhancing the catalytic active site density or by controlling the electronic structure by doping of N. In this work, 2D mesoporous N-doped activated carbon sheets were synthesized from the Acorus Calamus plant “root” part by a simple, facile route and used as efficient electrocatalysts for both HER and OER activity. The obtained N-doped activated carbons are found to have an excellent surface area with mesoporous structures. Further, the effect of synthesis temperature on the HER and OER activity was investigated. However, the optimized carbon pyrolyzed at 750 °C (C-750) exhibited appreciable electrocatalytic activity with an overpotential of -0.330 and 0.563 V vs. RHE at the current density of -10.0 mA/cm2. In addition, the C-750 catalyst also showed excellent stability with almost zero degradation in a chronoamperometric measurement carried out for 10 h. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and chemicals Acorus Calamus was collected from the local market in Keleampakam, the nearest SSN College of Engineering, Chennai. Potassium hydroxide (KOH), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP), Carbon Black, Hydrochloric acid (HCl), and Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) were purchased from SRL Chemicals. Carbon Cloth was purchased from Wee suppliers and used as a substrate. All chemicals were used directly without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis method Fig. 1 represents the synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets from Acorus Calamus by carbonization process under N2 atmosphere [44]. Initially, Acorus Calamus is washed with 1 M of HCl solution followed by DI water and then dried at 80 °C for 24 h to remove impurities. Then, the cleaned Acorus Calamus was cut into tiny pieces and dried at 80 °C for 6 h and then pre-heated at 200 °C for 12 h. The pre-heated pieces are subjected to a carbonization process at 450 °C for 4 h (5 °C/min) was carried out in a tubular furnace under continuous nitrogen flow in a programmable tubular furnace (C-450). After the carbonization, the powder was finely ground in a mortar and pestle in the presence of KOH pellets (stoichiometric ratio of 1:3) for 1 h. Then the KOH-treated powder is further carbonized at 750 °C for 4 h (5 °C/min) in a tubular furnace under continuous nitrogen flow in a programmable tubular furnace (C-750). After the carbonization, the black powder obtained was washed with DI and then dried in a hot-air oven at 80 °C for 24 h and then used directly for electrochemical studies. 2.3 Characterization techniques The graphitization of the obtained carbon catalysts was carried out by using the X-ray diffraction technique (PANalytical X'Pert Pro-with a diffractometer with CuKα rays (λ=1.5406 Å)). The Raman spectra of the carbon catalysts are analyzed from Renishaw (UK) spectrometer with an incident wavelength laser light of 632.8 nm. The FT-IR spectrum was obtained by a BRUKER OPTIK spectrometer, GMBH, Germany (Model No. TENSOR 27) using the KBr pellet technique. The elemental composition and oxidation state of the carbon particle was obtained from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis by using Thermo scientific Spectrometer (model: ESCALAB 250XI) with an XR6 micro-focused monochromator (Al−Kα XPS) XR4. Morphological analysis of the carbon particle was obtained from Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope using FEI Quanta FEG 200 HR-SEM. The particle size and structural properties were obtained from High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope using JEOL (JEM-2100 Plus) operating at 200 kV by coating a test carbon sample on a copper grid. The surface area and porosity of the carbon particles were analyzed from N2 sorption isotherms using quanta chrome autosorb instruments. The cyclic voltammetry (CV), Linear Sweep Voltameter (LSV), and Electrochemical Impedance (EIS) were analyzed for carbon nanoparticles using Versa STAT-3, Princeton Applied Research, USA. 2.4 Electrochemical characterization The carbon cloth is used as a substrate for carrying out electrochemical tests. Initially, carbon cloth was cleaned through a sonication process for 1 h using distilled water and ethanol and the obtained carbon cloth was dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h. Further, the dried cloth was immersed in concentrated HNO3 for 12 h and then washed with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone using bath-type sonication. Then the carbon cloth was dried at 60 °C in a vacuum oven for 12 h. The obtained carbon cloth was cut into 3.5 × 1 cm2 to be used as a substrate. The electrode pastes prepared by using synthesized carbon (5.6 mg), carbon black (1 mg), and PVDF (1 mg) were mixed. Subsequently, five drops of NMB solution were added and ground to make a slurry using mortar and pestle. The obtained slurry was coated on edge of carbon cloth with a 1 × 1 cm2 surface area and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 24 h and then used as a working electrode. The platinum (Pt) and Ag/AgCl were used as counter and reference electrodes, respectively. During the electrochemical analysis, KOH (1 M) was used as an electrolyte solution. 2.5 Result and discussion The XRD pattern of C-450 and C-750 have presented in Fig. 2 a. The XRD analysis shows peaks at 2θ=25° and 2θ=43° are related to the (002) and (100) planes, respectively. The C-750 particles show a slightly suppressed XRD peak intensity than that of C-450. This may be due to the crystallization process which is occurred during the KOH activation process. The XRD peak of both the C-450 and C-750 samples are possesses broad diffraction peaks and the C-750 is suppressed after the KOH etching, thereby crystallization is affected in C-750 [45]. The Debye-Scherrer formula [46,47] D = Kλ/βcosθ is used to calculate the crystallite size of the carbon particles from the (002) plane which reveals the crystallite size of C-450 is found to be 3.68 nm whereas the crystallite size of C-750 is decreased to 2.53 nm. The XRD analysis confirmed that the nitrogen-implanted C-750 effectively modifies the crystallite size more than that of C-450. Raman spectra of C-450 and C-750 are presented in Fig. 2b. The synthesized carbon particles show Raman peaks at 1589 and 1342 cm−1 are related to the G band (sp2 carbon with in-plane E2g) and the D band (A1g symmetry) respectively [48]. The Raman spectra of C-450 and C-750 show ID/IG ratio is 0.99 and 1.30 respectively. However, the C-750 sample has a high ID/IG ratio of around 1.32, confirming the existence of a high density of defect sites that significantly boost electrocatalytic activity by facile adsorption/desorption of O2, H +, and OH species on the activated carbon of the C-750 surface. The XPS survey spectra of C-750 shows the presence of carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen, with estimated atomic percentage (at%) of about 82.5, 5.2, and 12.3 at%, respectively (Fig. 3 a). Further, it is observed that the C/N and C/O ratios are about 15.86% and 6.70%, respectively. The C 1s deconvoluted spectra (Fig. 3b) show the presence of several chemical functionalities such as C=C, CC,−OH, and C=O peaks at the binding energies of ∼284.81, ∼286.81, and ∼288.71 eV respectively. The presence of C=C, and CC shows the presence of sp2 and sp3 hybridization of carbons in the catalyst [48]. Further, C1s spectra show a peak at 285.91 eV which is due to the presence of the C−N bond, confirming the doping of N into the carbon matrix. The N 1s deconvoluted spectra (Fig. 3c) reveal the presence of N in four different bonding states, namely, pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-Nand pyridine-N-oxide states, at the binding energies of ∼399.06, 400.01, 401.41, and ∼402.56 eV respectively. [49]. The N 1s core spectra reveal that the substitution of one carbon atom along with the nitrogen atom formed pyridinic-N (sp2 hybridization) in the carbon skeleton. Fig. 3d shows the deconvoluted spectra of O 1s which reveal two peaks at ∼531.71 eV and ∼533.36 eV are confirms the formation of C−OH and C=O oxygen functionalities respectively [50,51]. The existence of nitrogen along with carbon structure effectively promotes electrical conductivity, therefore in this present work, the electrochemical properties of C-750 may be increased than that of C-450. The TEM images of carbon C-750 are presented in Fig. 4 a which reveals the thin layered structure of carbon sheets. Further, it is confirmed that the C-750 contains a few layers of the irregular shape of the carbon nanosheets. The HRTEM analysis of C-750 is presented in Fig. 4b which reveals porous structures along with hierarchical honeycomb formation of the carbon particles. Further, the hieratical honeycomb structures are interconnected and then form tunnel-like channels. The HRTEM analysis possesses a huge number of white spots on the surface of C-750 which confirms the well-distributed microporous and graphitic carbon edges [52]. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of C-750 (Fig. 4c) shows a ring formation that confirms C-750 is polycrystalline. EDXA reveals the presence of carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen elements and no other impurities confirming the sample is pure. Furthermore, the obtained HRTEM results are well-matched with the XRD results. The TEM and HRTEM analyses of C-750 confirm that the structure is effectively varied due to the KOH activation process. Fig. 5 a shows nitrogen adsorption and desorption analysis of C-750 to analyze the surface area, pore size, and pore volume. BET measurement of C-750 reveals type-1 isotherm. Further, the BET surface area of the C-750 sample shows 3488 m²/g. Pore size and pore volume were obtained from Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method (Fig. 5b). Then the BJH model of C-750 shows a peak at 4.08 nm confirming the presence of mesoporous structure and pore volume is about 1.10 cc/g. The mesoporous structure occurs in C-750 this may be due to the presence of KOH along with the carbon particles has effectively enhanced the activation process and created the mesopores structures on the surface of C-750 [53]. The electrochemical analysis (both HER and OER) was carried out for C-450, C-750, bare Ni metal, and RuO2 by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) with a scan rate of 0.010 V/s using 1 M KOH as an electrolyte solution. During the electrochemical analysis, all the potentials were reported concerning the RHE reference electrode. The HER analysis of C-450, C-750, and bare Ni metal catalysts was evaluated and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 6 a. As expected, the LSV plot of C-450 shows poor electrochemical behavior toward HER activity. The C-450 sample shows onset potential and overpotential at 10 mA/cm2 were respectively at about -0.50 and -0.57 V vs. RHE; this may be due to their poor surface area, low conductivity, and low redox active sites occurred in the C-450. While the KOH-activated sample of C-750 shows significantly improved HER activity when compared with that of C-450. The enrichment in HER activity is observed from the C-750 which reveals that the low onset potential is about -0.103 V vs RHE and overpotential at 10 mA/cm2 is observed at about -0.33 V vs. RHE. Further, the bare Ni metal shows the onset potential is about -0.023 V vs RHE and the overpotential is -0.078 V vs. RHE at 10 mA/cm2. In the present work, the obtained LSV results of C-750 reveal relatively better results when compared with that of C-450 and bare Ni metal. Fig. 6b shows the Tafel slopes were plotted for C-450 and C-750 bare Ni metal which shows the slope value respectively about 1.373, 0.420, and 0.17 V/dec (vs RHE). Fig. 6c shows the bar chat of onset potential, at 10 mA/cm2 current density and over the potential for the sample of C-450, C-750, and bare Ni metal respectively. Further, we confirmed the stability of C-750 in 1 M of KOH using chronoamperometry measurement at a constant potential of -0.47 V vs. RHE (Fig. 6d) shows a current density of about -22 mA/cm2 which confirms better stability for a time period of 10 h. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) analysis was evaluated for C-450 and C-750 at different scan rates and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 7 a and b. Further, the current density (∆j) was calculated from the difference between anodic and cathodic peak current density (ja-jc). The plot of scan rate vs. current density will give the information of double layer capacitance (Cdl ). During the HER analysis, C-450 and C-750 reveal the 2 µF/cm2 and 164 µF/cm2, respectively (Fig. 7c, d). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis shows the charge transfer resistance (Rct ) of C-450 and C-750 respectively about 700 and 200 ohms (Fig. 7e). It is confirmed in the present work, the C-750 reveals better HER performance than that of C-450. Further, we investigated the OER activity of C-450, C-750, and RuO2 catalysts, and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 8 a. The LSV plot of C-450 shows a poor initial onset potential (2.17 V vs. RHE), a poor potential of about 2.26 V vs. RHE at 10 mA/cm2, and a poor overpotential of 1.03 V vs. RHE. Whereas the LSV plot of RuO2 shows initial onset potential, the potential at 10 mA/ cm2 is about 1.48 and 1.57 V (vs. RHE) respectively. Further, RuO2 shows over potential is 0.345 V vs. RHE at 10 mA/cm2 current density. The optimized sample of C-750 shows initial onset potential, the potential at 10 mA/ cm2 about 1.68 and 1.793 V (vs. RHE) respectively. Further, the calculated overpotential of C-750 is 0.563 V vs. RHE at 10 mA/cm2 current density. Tafel slopes were plotted for C-450, C-750 RuO2 (Fig. 8b) shows the slope value respectively about 0.474, 0.071, and 0.117 V/dec (vs RHE). However, the optimized sample of C-750 shows a relatively less slope value than that of C-450 and RuO2. Fig. 8c shows the comparative bar chat of onset potential, at 10 mA/cm2 current density and over the potential for the sample of C-450, C-750, and RuO2 respectively. Fig. 8d shows the stability of C-750 in 1 M of KOH using chronoamperometry measurement at a constant potential of 1.846 V vs. RHE which possesses the current density of about 23 mA/cm2 which confirms better stability for a time period of 10 h. Further, CV analysis of C-450 and C-750 were performed at different scan rates and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 9 a and b. Further, the current density (∆j) was calculated from the difference between anodic and cathodic peak current density (ja-jc). The plot of scan rate vs. current density will give the information of double layer capacitance (Cdl ). During the HER analysis, C-450 and C-750 reveal 2.4 µF/cm2 and 6.3 µF/cm2, respectively (Fig. 9c,d). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis shows the charge transfer resistance (Rct ) of C-450 and C-750 respectively about 100 and 25 ohms (Fig. 9e). It is confirmed in the present work, the C-750 reveals better HER performance than that of C-450. Further, the present work results are compared with the previous reports and it is presented in Table 1 . It is observed that the metal-free catalysts, nitrogen-doped activated carbon nanoparticles reveal enhancement of electrochemical performance than that of un-activated carbon nanoparticles. 3 Conclusion In summary, carbon nanoparticles were synthesized and activated using KOH through the carbonization process from the biomass of Acorus Calamus. The XRD analysis reveals that the crystallite size of C-450 was 3.68 nm. Further, the crystallite size was effectively reduced to 2.53 nm for the activated sample of C-750. The KOH-activated C-750 reveals enhancement of BET surface area of about 3488 m²/g and forms the mesoporous structure on the carbon sheets. The pore size and pore volume of the C-750 sample were determined as 4.08 nm and 1.10 cc/g, respectively. The HRTEM analysis confirms that the C-750 carbon nanosheets contain microporous structures on the surfaces. The enhancement of surface area and pore size distribution of C-750 effectively enhances the electrochemical activity towards both HER and OER analysis under the alkaline medium. The HER activity of C-750 exhibits low-onset potential (-0.103 V vs. RHE) and low overpotential of -0.33 V vs. RHE at -10.0 mA/cm2 along with a Tafel value was observed at 0.420 mV/dec at a current density of about -20 mA/cm2. On the other side, the C-750 catalyst reveals better OER activity with a low-onset potential of 1.68 V vs. RHE and an overpotential of 0.563 V vs. RHE at 10.0 mA/cm2 with a small Tafel slope of 0.071 V/dec. coredata.dc:description: Production of “green hydrogen” through water electrolysis is attracting considerable attention in recent years, due to the high demand for green energy technologies. The efficiency of water electrolysis depends on the electrocatalytic activity of anodic and cathodic electrocatalysts. Currently, utilizing Pt and RuO2-based electrocatalysts is expensive in terms of commercial aspects. Therefore, growing research for inventing efficient and cheap electrocatalysts is undergoing rigorously. In this work, we have synthesized, biomass-derived electrocatalysts with intrinsically implanted heteroatoms as hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions in alkaline electrolytes. The biomass carbon catalyst is derived from the carbonation of the Acorus Calamus plant “root”. The derived carbon is activated by KOH treatment (C-750). The resultant carbon powder is characterized by various physiochemical and electrochemical characterization techniques. The C-750 catalyst is found to have excellent morphology, surface area (3488 m²/g), pore size (4.08 nm), pore volume (1.10 cc/g), and intrinsically doped N. The HRTEM analysis of C-750 reveals well-distributed microporous and graphitic surfaces. When used as an electrocatalyst for HER and OER analysis, the C-750 exhibited appreciable electrocatalytic activity with an overpotential of -0.330 V and 0.563 V vs. RHE, respectively at the current density of -10.0 mA/cm2. In addition, the C-750 catalyst also showed excellent stability with almost zero degradation in a chronoamperometric measurement carried out for 10 hrs.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and characterization of metal-free nanosheets of carbo-catalysts for bifunctional electrocatalyst towards HER and OER application
